Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Galaxy Evolution and Missing Satellites with ALMA and Gravitational Lensing
Award.AbstractNarration: A significant fraction of the energy in the universe has been absorbed and re-emitted by dust, in dusty star-forming galaxies (DSFGs). Most of the star formation in the universe at cosmological redshifts between 2 and 3 may have taken place in such galaxies and emitted no visible or ultraviolet light because of dust obscuration. Using the NSF- and DOE-funded South Pole Telescope (SPT), the proposing team has identified approximately 100 bright DSFGs, all of which are magnified and brightened by gravitational lensing. They now intend to use the Atacama Large Millimeter/Submillimeter Array (ALMA) to observe these galaxies, obtaining spectroscopic redshifts, measuring elemental abundances, and inferring the distribution of dark matter. The goals are to determine the distribution of DSFGs in redshift, the physical conditions in their interstellar media, and the mass function of dark matter substructure. As a broader impact, the proposers intend to develop new interferometric analysis tools that incorporate self-calibration as a modeled uncertainty for gravitationally lensed objects. The project will support the work of two graduate students, and the PI will conduct outreach presentations and develop undergraduate laboratory exercises on interferometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied a sample of approximately 100 of the brightest extragalactic far-infrared sources in the sky, discovered by the South Pole Telescope in a survey of the southern sky. Initial investigations showed these objects to be very distant, massive, rapidly star-forming galaxies, seen when the universe was less than 25% of its current age. Nearly all of these galaxies are also magnified by the gravity of intervening galaxies, which presents opportunities to study them in greater detail and to learn about the dark matter surrounding the lens galaxies, thereby testing the current cosmological model.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes: We have used the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) to obtain redshifts, derive lens models, and produce detailed images of these distant galaxies. Our work has measured the physical conditions under which these galaxies are forming stars at exceptionally high rates, observed outflowing gas that shows the process by which star formation prevents future star formation, and discovered the most distant galaxy of this type, less than 800 million years after the Big Bang (6% of its current age). We have also significantly improved techniques for removing the distorting effects of gravitational lensing. One application of this capability has been to detect the presence of a dark matter structure within the swarm of dark matter that is responsible for lensing a background galaxy, which demonstrates that we can test the dominant cosmological model with more observations of this kind.

Broader Impact Outcomes: This award has directly supported three graduate students in PhD programs in Arizona and Illinois. Three graduate students at other universities have closely collaborated in the work of this award. Four of these students have completed their research training and received PhDs during the award period. In addition, more than 10 undergraduates have had research opportunities in Arizona and Illinois under this program. The results of this work have been presented to hundreds of students in introductory classes at both institutions, as examples of various astronomical phenomena and the process of scientific research. Data from this project has been used to train both undergraduate and graduate students in practical aspects of analyzing data from interferometers.
